summary: influenza is an important cause of annual morbidity and mortality that can be prevented with vaccination. 5 Influenza virus infections contribute substantially to the annual burden of respiratory illness in temperate regions of the globe. there is a growing body of evidence to suggest that this is also the case in tropical regions. the surveillance system in Abidjan was expanded to 14 sites in 2007. twelve additional sites were added during 2008 through 2010, of which five were located in abidjan. nine were located in the interior of the country with an emphasis on the eastern region. 5074 NP specimens were analyzed for the detection of influenza viruses. all sentinel specimens (n = 867) were tested using viral culture. viral culture was also performed on a subset of RTPCRpositive cases to have influenza viruses available for antigenic characterization. influenza viruses were detected in culture using the ELISA immunocapture method. a hemmaglutination test with 05% red blood cells of chicken was performed on the culture supernatant after 48 hours of incubation. from 2008, cell culture was performed on only the positive samples in RTPCR. three multiplex heminested RTPCR assays were carried out as described by BellauPujol S et al. for the detection of other respiratory viruses, 12 targeting the following 12 RNA respiratory viruses simultaneously. influenzapositive specimens were sent either to the Institute Pasteur in Paris or to the WHO Collaborating Centers in Atlanta and/or London for more advanced analysis. the surveillance data were analyzed to evaluate temporal trends in the number of ILI cases and the percent of those cases testing positive for influenza at the sentinel sites. the first seven healthcare centers that were selected to be sentinel surveillance sites were located in the city of Abidjan. these sites were selected using the following criteria: geographic representation within Abidjan; adequate throughput of patients consulting at the health facility; the existence of a department of general medicine, a pediatric department, and a laboratory; the accessibility of the site; and availability of a refrigerator (+4°C) for the storage of specimens. virocult swabs were collected from each ILI case using virocult swabs (Medical Wire and Equipment, UK) and stored in a sterile cryovial containing a viral transport medium (VTM) Specimens were kept at +4°C following collection and during transport. a subset of respiratory specimens was collected within 3 days of first symptom onset. of the 1782
